comments.commentBody: Yes it does, I bet the list came from some educated people and he will only select one with further advice.  Unlike Obama he is not the smartest person in the room.  For example when he fixed the skating rink, he found the best to do that and then let them perform.  He investigated or had his staff do so.   This is how people in business  do things.

My mistake with the quotation about sales of 1984 in my previous comment, this is the story relating to very recent increases in sales of this novel ...

'Sales are soaring for George Orwell's "1984" in the wake of incorrect or unprovable statements made by President Donald Trump and some White House aides.

Orwell's classic dystopian tale of a society in which facts are distorted and suppressed in a cloud of "newspeak" was in the top 5 on Amazon.com as of midday on Tuesday. '

http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/25/1984-sales-soar-alternative-f...

They would if they could. Republicans want to run these guys through fast and have cut off further questioning. All the Democrats can expect to do is inform the public what they themselves see and know, which contrasts how perfect and smart they are, according to Trump. Gag orders preventing further discussion of Trump will be issued soon. I think the people are just now beginning to wake up to the fact that they are the victims of a successful coop d'état.

Ivanka and Jared just had a hearty laugh. Donald doesn't laugh - at all. But the very last thing he cares about is goodwill. But "bold steps" he is planning on making. None of it will inspire goodwill.

What most people are "aghast" about is the flagrant abuse of power and anti-constitutional tactics the Republican Congress used to "ignore" Judge Garland's nomination while Mr. Obama was the standing president, for no other reason than to wait out his presidency.  For the people who voted for Obama, it was the SUPREME middle finger.   We all know what the conservatives wanted when they failed to do their constitutional duty, and thanks to former President Obama's grace, he didn't use the powers he had to force Judge Garland down your throats.  You do know that he, legally, of course, could have.  But he did not, because that's the kind of decent man he is.  So now, yes, you WILL win.  YAYYY for you.  You will succeed in placing a "bought and paid for" right-wing lackey on the Supreme Court, under specious circumstances,  for one reason only, to serve your SELFISH political aims.  The US Constitution be damned.   You all knew what you are doing, and you can trust me,  WE WILL NEVER FORGET.

I voted for Bernie and think Trump is a dangerous megalomaniac.
I personally know one of these three, and am aware of no reason why he should not be confirmed. He is a fair judge, an insightful jurist, and a good man.
Voted for Bernie, aka "Voted for Trump".
And, was Merrick Garland also those things? Was there any reason he should not have been appointed, other than he is just another white male in a sea of white male authority right now?
Which one?

Republicans refused to confirm Judge Garland and Democrats now appear ready to reject any Trump appointee. Whatever happened to " when they go low, we go high"? In 2013 Democrats employed the "nuclear option" eliminating the filibuster for appointees to cabinet positions and judicial appointments below the Supreme Court. Now Republicans have the same option. This tit for tat is deplorable and neither party will have clean hands in this fight which mirrors the awful divisive nature of our current politics. Can no one rise above this bitter partisan divide?
Love it!!
@jk-- how bout "sheets" Byrd?

I do remember Thurmond and Helms. I also remember George C. Wallace. Goodness and decency are not the sole province of either party but the belief that one party embodies good and the other evil is what has landed us where we are.
McConnell said the people should be heard. The majority voted for Clinton.  So, what's the problem, Mitch?

Is there any doubt it will be Judge Pryor.  Trump has big bills to pay with donors, Evangelicals, and his alt-right base.  But more to the point, Trump has scores to settle with those who oppose him: Pryor will be his kick-in-the-teeth revenge.
Does Pryor have a black robe to go with his white robe?

He's got a JD, he was a US Attorney. Since when does Trump care about qualifications? Carson? DeVos? Perry? Kushner? Bannon? Nada. Zilch. Puppets to do biddings of the right christian extremists. Giuliani got a bone tossed to him, finally, and Christie still needs his pay off. And he's out of a job in NJ after this term ends this fall. So he needs a new gig.

But no, Christie isn't going to get it, it's just that Trump likes batting him around like a half-dead mouse.

For the foreseeable future justices will be confirmed only when the President and the Senate majority are of the same party.  Trump will get the Scalia seat, and odds are good that at least one of the four liberal seats will be picked up.  It's also possible that Kennedy and/or Thomas will retire, allowing for the appointment of younger conservatives.

Ricky:

At the press conference today Spicer was asked about this. He said that trump still owned stock in Energy Transfer Partners - but then minimized the implication of that by saying it was only a "couple of thousands of dollars" that he owned - and that was nothing for a "billionaire".

And you're exactly right - we have no idea what if anything trump sold. Personally I don't think he truly felt he was going to win the election and that coupled with his refusal to divest himself now - I find it not believable that he sold his stock holdings in June.

If he did sell all his stocks - why is his press secretary now stating he owns some shares in ETP. Since we have no information, it's impossible to know just how large an investment he does have in ETP.
They are all strong decisions agreed to by a prior majority of the Supreme Court and are res judicata. Disregarding them is alternative justice.

The reason Medicare exists is precisely because there is no business model that works for providing insurance for the elderly. Who would be dumb enough to write health insurance for someone in their 80s?

The insurance companies have passed off the loss leaders to the taxpayers and kept the profitable market for themselves. (So actually single payer would also save Medicare as well, but stupid people would believe the insurance companies, so it's impossible. )

But, this isn't because they are evil or something, it's how it has to work in a free market, which is why Arrow proved the free market can't provide health care efficiently.
The seat is not "Scalia's Seat"; he lost it when he died. There is no requirement to fill it with a Scalia's clone. I support Merrick Garland for the VACANT seat.
Garland's nomination has expired.

I'll accept any atheist.

It would honor our secular roots and founders.

Going high when he goes low is not very effective against Trump. Going high looks like weakness. People tune it out. Going high leaves Trump supporters with their opinions and attachments. Going low does not work either, since he is the master of low and, more important, going low is not a good way to make important decisions.

Some who do not like Trump are going humorous, but the humor should be more than just cheap shots. It should strip away pretense and reveal the reality behind it. Cheap shots about hair or hands should be a part of a routine that provokes thought or realization as well as laughter.

We have decided to do an experiment with ourselves, to try something else. We should not be as concerned with blocking the parts of this experiment as we are with making sure that its results are widely known and not hidden. Since part of our experiment is to hide reality behind giant steaming mounds of alternate facts, revealing the absurdity of these giant steaming mounds will cut away at their effectiveness.

I'm not sure how you define "going high." I see it as taking my seat in my integrity, acknowledging inside myself my rage and my disgust, but putting the energy that comes from those feelings into intelligent action. "Going high" isn't about some weird, pollyanna notion of dignity. It's about being real, being willing to be courageously real, and yet stepping apart from methods that create further harm. There are plenty of ways to call out what's happening, to call Trump and Co. on the carpet, and still remain seated in our values.
I.e., when they go low, we go bill maher (out not-so-secret weapon).  Love that guy.
At the present rate, the Dems are going to sorely miss your dime.

When Democrats keep harping about garland, GOP should remind them of the disgraceful way they treated Robert Bork.

As for their unrelenting opposition, It was obstructionism when the other party did it.........

Teddy Kennedy was a rank demagogue when it came to Mr. Bork, but his actions were openly celebrated by the left. The left has no conception how badly that episode offended Republicans and set the stage for continuing bitterness. Kennedy was a vicious, unprincipled man, and he led the charge.
For the umpteenth time, Bork got a hearing and was voted down. The Senate did their duty. They are required to hold hearings. They are not required to rubber stamp the nomination.
Bork got a hearing. Garland did not.

When Scalia was alive, there were three who almost always voted together, Scalia, Thomas, Alito. There were four who ALWAYS voted together on controversial issues on a purely partisan basis, those appointed by Democrats. And then there were two, Kennedy and Roberts, who no one ever knew how that were going to vote until after the decisions were read. The Roberts court was never a 5/4 court. It was a 3/2/4 court. It is now a 2/2/4 court.

Name a single controversial case where one of the partisan Democrats ever voted with the four or five Republican appointed justices.

Garland is not a moderate or centrist. Had Garland been confirmed, the partisan "living constitution" wing would have block voted every single controversial issue. Had Trump's election been challenged, they'd have given it to Hillary because she had the popular plurality. If you look at Garland's record, he has never, ever voted to constrain the executive branch.

The judiciary, in general, is expected to grant deference to the elected branches of government on political choices. Although I disagreed with Robert's on the ObamaCare decision, in his decision he said that it was up to the legislature to cure the obvious defects in the law, not for the judiciary to substitute their judgement.

But we are dependent on the judiciary to point out when the executive branch, rather than executing the law as written, writes new rules unilaterally. Garland has never done that.

WGN led the TV news with this story. A group of about 50 blacks on the South Side said the only thing that will help is bringing in the National Guard. And these are the people who live in the middle of the chaos.

But if you think Chicago is all hunky-dory with 42 murders by January 24, then OK!! Tell that to the people who aren't delighted with living in the midst of Murderville.

if the senate regains a democratic majority in 2018, would you be okay with them blocking any of his appointments until the next election?

because that's what the republicans did this time around. remember, you reap what you sow.
The same should be said of Merrick Garland, whose nomination was stonewalled by #Republicants
Much like Merrick Garland?
Congratulations to those who selected Hilary as the Democrat candidate; Many of us saw this train coming long ago.

I would be appalled if Democrats do not fight tooth and nail over this nomination.  Republicans committed a political crime last year right in plain public view, and if Democrats do not have a proportional response then they will effectively be rolling over and signalling to the Republicans that they can do the same thing again and again.  It will cause permanent institutional damage to both the Senate and the Supreme Court.

Prepare to be appalled when the filibuster rule is shoved, thanks to harry reid's caustic mien, and as the pallbeares pass with each passing year, prepare to be appalled at the looming 7-2 conservative majority...until your grandkids are parents.  Nicely done, liberals!
